items.content_html:
Just reading this post by @chriscoyier@front-end.social, which is about the websites used to train Google‚Äôs AI. Was really surprised to see my little site listed there! üò≥

Was nice to be asked‚Ä¶

Google should be encouraging and fighting for the open web. But now they‚Äôre like, actually we‚Äôre just going to suck up your website, put it in a blender with all other websites, and spit out word smoothies for people instead of sending them to your website.

Hear, hear, Chris
items.content_text: Just reading [this post](https://chriscoyier.net/2023/04/21/the-secret-list-of-websites/) by [@chriscoyier@front-end.social](https://front-end.social/@chriscoyier), which is about the websites used to train Google‚Äôs AI. Was really surprised to see my little site listed there! üò≥ Was nice to be asked‚Ä¶ > Google should be encouraging and fighting for the open web. But now they‚Äôre like, actually we‚Äôre just going to suck up your website, put it in a blender with all other websites, and spit out word smoothies for people instead of sending them to your website. Hear, hear, Chris

items.content_html:
I miss likes/favourites/whatevers

I know Micro.blog purposely doesn‚Äôt have ‚Äúlikes‚Äù but I miss them. Not because I want to be silently praised by internet peeps, but because I want to give likes. I see them as a kind of silent feedback. Like if you‚Äôre in a pub talking and someone gives a knowing nod, or a smile.

I want to be able to give the virtual equivalent of that silent nod. That passive appreciation for what I just read.

Likes are silent communication and I miss them. Not everything requires a reply‚Ä¶
items.content_text:
**I miss likes/favourites/whatevers**

I know Micro.blog purposely doesn‚Äôt have ‚Äúlikes‚Äù but I miss them. Not because I want to be silently praised by internet peeps, but because I want to _give_ likes. I see them as a kind of silent feedback. Like if you‚Äôre in a pub talking and someone gives a knowing nod, or a smile.

I want to be able to give the virtual equivalent of that silent nod. That passive appreciation for what I just read.

Likes are silent communication and I miss them. Not everything requires a reply‚Ä¶

99.9% sure I‚Äôm gonna migrate from Jekyll at this point.
items.content_text:
So far I‚Äôm **incredibly** impressed with [Blot](https://blot.im). The service has all the advantages of an SSG with none of the hassle. The support by the creator, David, is also superbly good.

99.9% sure I‚Äôm gonna migrate from Jekyll at this point.

‚ÅâÔ∏è Here‚Äôs a question for you fine people‚Ä¶

If you‚Äôre visiting someone‚Äôs blog, do you ever check out the categories/tags of their posts, or don‚Äôt you care?

I don‚Äôt think I can recall a single time that I‚Äôve used cats/tags one someone‚Äôs blog, especially if they have a search box.

Is that just me?

items.content_html:
üîó Is Good Enough…Good Enough?

This is something I’ve been ruminating on recently, whilst going down the familiar “is my current blog platform the right one?” rabbit hole.
items.content_text:
üîó [Is Good Enough...Good Enough?](https://kevquirk.com/is-good-enough-good-enough/)

Nice family walk today. We did a little over 7km in the Welsh (hilly) countryside. Particularly impressed with my 5 year old. We got home just as the heavens opened too, so didn‚Äôt get too wet.

Now it‚Äôs time for cups of tea and bacon bagels! ü•Ø üë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüë¶‚Äçüë¶ üêæ üì∏

items.content_html:
After my brief foray into self-hosting a Microblog (via Wordpress) I decided it would be easier to let @manton and the team worry about plugging the many parts together, so I can just enjoy the community.

So, I‚Äôm very happy to be back here on Micro.blog. üòä
items.content_text:
After my brief foray into self-hosting a Microblog (via Wordpress) I decided it would be easier to let [@manton](https://micro.blog/manton) and the team worry about plugging the **many** parts together, so I can just enjoy the community.

So, I‚Äôm very happy to be back here on Micro.blog. üòä

items.content_html:
Unfortunately, @davatron5000@mastodon.social sadly lost his dog, Rudy. This post brought a tear to my eye, especially since I‚Äôm a fellow dog owner with an old girl too.

I‚Äôm so so sorry for your loss, Dave.
items.content_text:
Unfortunately, [@davatron5000@mastodon.social](https://micro.blog/davatron5000@mastodon.social) sadly lost his dog, [Rudy](https://daverupert.com/2023/04/goodbye-rudy/). This post brought a tear to my eye, especially since I‚Äôm a fellow dog owner with an old girl too.

I‚Äôm so so sorry for your loss, Dave.

items.content_html:
One of my sons really enjoys drawing, and he decided he wanted to draw one of my watches. He chose the cheapest watch in my collection, one of my Casio F-91W.

He drew that, then asked to draw another, of course he chose the most expensive watch in my collection. üò≥

items.content_html:
Are there any other people here who manage their blog and microblog separately? I‚Äôm still trying to work out what that‚Äôs gonna look like long term, but I have no plans to fold my main blog into Micro.blog.

If you keep them separate, what‚Äôs that workflow look like for you?
items.content_text:
Are there any other people here who manage their blog and microblog separately? I‚Äôm still trying to work out what that‚Äôs gonna look like long term, but I have no plans to fold my main blog into Micro.blog.

If you keep them separate, what‚Äôs that workflow look like for you?

items.content_html:
onemanandhisblog.com

Does it matter if Substack is in financial trouble?

Really interesting post by @adders about the potential demise of Substack. I know a couple of people who have made Substack their home on the web. It might be time to start looking for alternatives, folks. üòû

items.content_html: I‚Äôve just been looking at the Apple passwords feature, since lots of people are talking about it at the moment (I‚Äôm a Bitwarden user) and it looks very good. I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd use it though. I like the idea of having something like my passwords on its own service. Apple already have enough of my data, they don‚Äôt need passwords too.

items.content_html:
bt.ht

Stop Using Custom Web Fonts

I‚Äôm not sure I agree with Brad here. Well, for the most part I do, but I have a font on my site, and I use it because I really like how it looks. That all, that‚Äôs the reason. üòä

I‚Äôve also had a few people comment about the font, so some people clearly do appreciate custom fonts. Agree though, performance still needs to be a key factor.
items.content_text:
[bt.ht](https://bt.ht/webfonts)

> Stop Using Custom Web Fonts

I‚Äôm not sure I agree with Brad here. Well, for the most part I do, but I have a font on my site, and I use it because I really like how it looks. That all, that‚Äôs the reason. üòä

I‚Äôve also had a few people comment about the font, so *some* people clearly do appreciate custom fonts. Agree though, performance still needs to be a key factor.

items.content_html:
I hear a lot of Americans saying ‚ÄúI went for a hike today‚Ä¶‚Äù in posts that are accompanied by often beautiful pictures of the US vast and varied landscape.

But what is ‚Äúa hike‚Äù to your average American? Because to me (British), a hike is a 20 mile hike up a large hill/mountain. Is it the same?
